The rule so set out reads as follows General rules as to appeals  a  Against an order of, dismissal, removal reduction, withholding of promotion or peri- odical increment there shall be one appeal in each case as follows Against an order passed by a Superintendent, to the Deputy InspectorGeneral Against an original order passed by a Deputy Inspector General, to the Inspector General Against an original order passed by the Inspector-General, to the Local Government. issues.text: The question is whether it was competent for the Government, in an appeal filed by the appellant against the said order of reversion passed by the Inspector-General Police, to set aside the findings of that officer by which he exonerated the appellant from the said charges against him, which findings were number appealed against by the department, and then pass an order of dismissal accepting the findings of the enquiry officer.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether it was competent for the Government, in an appeal filed by the appellant against the said order of reversion passed by the Inspector-General Police, to set aside the findings of that officer by which he exonerated the appellant from the said charges against him,

issues.text: whether the State Government can interfere with an order passed by the Inspector-General under s. 7 in exercise of the power conferred on him by that section under the purported exercise of the general power of superintendence under s. 3 unless there is some provision which authorises or envisages such interference

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the State Government cannot interfere with, under the purported exercise of the general power of superintendence under s. 3 with an order passed by any one of the officers mentioned in S. 7 in exercise of the power conferred on them by that section, unless there is some provision which authorises or envisages such interference.

issues.text: whether an appellate authority in an appeal by an aggrieved party can impose on such an appellant a higher penalty and condemn him to a position worse than the one he would be in if he had not hazarded to file an appeal

whether the order of reversion passed by the Inspector-General on the basis of adverse remarks was valid when the adverse remarks were never notified to the appellant nor was any opportunity to explain those remarks afforded to him before the order of reversion was passed

holdings.text: The State Government cannot interfere with an order passed by the Inspector-General under s.7 Police Act using general superintendence power under s.3 unless authorised by some provision.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the State Government cannot interfere with, under the purported exercise of the general power of superintendence under s. 3 with an order passed by any one of the officers mentioned in S. 7 in exercise of the power conferred on them by that section, unless there is some provision which authorises or envisages such interference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific powers conferred by s.7 on IG must qualify general superintendence in s.3; harmonious reading prevents override without explicit authorisation.

holdings.text: In the appellant's appeal under r.851(b) against reversion only, the Government lacked competence to set aside IG's exoneration findings on charges (not appealed by department) and impose dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: r. 851 set out by the High Court in its judgment in the first writ, petition filed by the appellant, reported in Makeshwar Nath vs. Bihar 1 . The rule so set out reads as follows General rules as to appeals  a  Against an order of, dismissal, removal reduction, withholding of promotion or peri- odical increment there shall be one appeal in each case as follows Against an order passed by a Superintendent, to the Deputy InspectorGeneral Against an original order passed by a Deputy Inspector General, to the Inspector General Against an original order passed by the Inspector-General, to the Local Government. The order of the appellate authority on any such appeal shall be final. Under this rule an appeal would lie before the Government against the order of the Inspector-General reverting

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.851(b) limits appellate jurisdiction to matters in the filed appeal; no departmental appeal against exoneration; cannot review unappealed findings.

holdings.text: The order of dismissal passed by the Government in the appeal filed by the appellant was not sustainable.

anchor.surface_text: The order of dismissal passed by the Government in the appeal filed by the appellant therefore, was not sustainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal exceeded appellate power under r.851(b) as it reviewed unappealed exoneration and enhanced penalty.

holdings.text: Government could not exercise revision under r.853 as an appeal had been filed before it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Revision power under r.853 intended when no appeal possible; appeal filed precludes revision.

holdings.text: The dismissal order cannot be sustained under r.853-A as the rule was neither produced nor proven to be notified in the official gazette as required by s.46(2).
holdings.reasoning_summary: No production of rule or evidence of gazette notification per s.46(2); cannot rely on unproven rule.

holdings.text: An appellate authority cannot impose a higher penalty or condemn the appellant to a worse position than if no appeal had been filed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle limits appellate power to avoid deterring appeals; can only uphold, modify or set aside appealed order without enhancement.

holdings.text: The High Court was not right in dismissing the writ petition; appeal allowed, State Government's dismissal order quashed as without jurisdiction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of lack of jurisdiction under relevant rules and statutes renders dismissal void; reinstatement follows.

The appeal has, therefore, to be allowed and the order of the State Government quashed as being without jurisdiction.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment reversed; State Government's dismissal order quashed without jurisdiction; appellant deemed never dismissed and continued in police force.
directions: The consequence is as if the appellant was never dismissed, and continued to remain in the police force to which he was attached.
